results.title: Evva Hanes, Who Made Moravian Cookies World Famous, Dies at 90

results.title: Drowning Is No. 1 Killer of Young Children. U.S. Efforts to Fix It Are Lagging.
results.abstract: Thirty years of progress in decreasing drowning deaths in the United States appears to have plateaued, and disparities in deaths among some racial groups have worsened.

media.caption: The sisters Adalynn and Sinclaire Wallace, 9 and 7, took a break during a swim lesson at Salgado Community Center in Santa Ana, Calif.

results.title: The End of the Magic World’s 50-Year Grudge
results.abstract: In 1973, Uri Geller claimed to bend metal with his mind on live television. Skeptics couldn’t beat him. Now they’ve joined him.

media.caption: Uri Geller became a global celebrity and the living embodiment of the hope that there was something more, something science couldn’t explain.

results.byline: By Alan Rappeport, Lisa Friedman and Keith Bradsher
results.title: Yellen Urges China to Step Up Climate Finance Investments
results.abstract: Janet Yellen, the Treasury secretary, said China, the largest emitter of greenhouse gases, can have “greater impact” tackling climate change by working with other nations.

media.caption: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen during a climate meeting at the U.S. Embassy in Beijing on Saturday. She said that China, like the United States, has a responsibility to be a climate finance leader.

results.title: Millions Danced Joyfully to Her Song. She Drew on Her Pain to Write It.
results.abstract: Nomcebo Zikode, the South African singer of the pandemic hit “Jerusalema” that inspired a global dance challenge, wrote the chorus while battling her own depression.

media.caption: Nomcebo Zikode, performing in Johannesburg, wrote the chorus to the global hit “Jerusalema” in 2019. While the song brought her global renown, she is still fighting for financial reward.
media.copyright: Alexia Webster for The New York Times

results.title: A Top U.K. Newspaper Explores Its Ties to Slavery, and Britain’s
results.abstract: In a multimedia series, The Guardian becomes the latest British institution to confront — and apologize for — its role in the slave trade.

media.caption: The Guardian produced a multimedia series this year called “Cotton Capital: How Slavery Changed The Guardian, Britain and the World.”

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Classical Music;Jazz;Nero, Peter;Philly Pops;Philadelphia (Pa)
results.title: Peter Nero, Pianist Who Straddled Genres, Is Dead at 89
results.abstract: He soared to popularity with a swinging hybrid of classics and jazz. He later conducted the Philly Pops, often with one hand while the other played piano.

media.caption: The pianist Peter Nero in an undated photo. A remarkable interpreter of Gershwin, he was also a natural showman.
